awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Building Social Infrastructure for Achieving Change at Scale
awd_abstract_narration:
The emergent field of engineering education research is a necessary lever to make systemic and sustainable changes in the way we educate and develop engineers to meet current and future national priorities and global challenges. There is a great deal of variation in the strength of the social infrastructure used by engineering education researchers to collaborate and build research projects of sufficient depth and diversity for true systemic change. In this project, relative social infrastructure strength is grouped as follows: those researchers who are connected to a department of engineering education; those who are connected to a center or other non-department, formalized group on their campus; and those who have neither connection. Any combination of access types may be present on a single campus. The purpose of this project is to discover and implement evidence-based social infrastructure elements that meet the needs of the third group while maintaining the integrity of the department- and center-based infrastructure. These researchers are often located in their universities in capacities that are highly intertwined with the practice of engineering education; finding better ways to network and support them creates stronger ties between research and practice, facilitating systemic and lasting change. 

Using the social movement organizing methodology of relational meetings, the investigators will conduct a series of interviews with engineering education researchers who are connected with centers or departments those who are not, and their practitioner colleagues to identify areas of common concern, resources each can contribute to change agent networks, and opportunities for strategic intervention around which the engineering education change movement can build power. Through two phases of the research root cause analysis will be applied to the problems of faculty reward structures and diversity in engineering; working at the level of structural economic forces in higher education in the first case, and racism, sexism, ableism, and other forms of structural inequality in the second case, will guide strategies and interventions to produce lasting, significant change and address problems at their source. This approach will further the research on change in engineering education by understanding faculty behavior as grounded not only in personal motivation and institutional reward structures but also in current economic and policy frameworks for higher education. The results of this project will identify mechanisms to strengthen engineering education networks. Of particular importance are those researchers currently working in the field who are not strongly connected to those networks. Broad-based and widespread change will occur through modifications to communities' infrastructure and leadership development that support both the engineering education researchers and practitioners.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

por.por_cntn:
The goals of this project were to (1) Identify opportunities for strengthening engineering education research networks; and (2) Leverage a combination of social movement theories of change with organizational behavior strategies to strengthen and grow engineering education research networks focused on achieving change at scale.

One of the identified problems in Engineering Education Research is the reliance of our research network on a small number of well-connected researchers who keep our field interconnected. There is a need to provide a stronger web of connection and support to those who are less well connected: the lone wolves. We define a "lone wolf" in Engineering Education Research (EER) as a researcher with minimal access to local infrastructure in EER (such as that provided by departments and centers for enigneering education research), minimal access to the local and national EER networks, or both. It is important to note that removing access to just one of these, infrastructure or network, still puts the individual researcher into the lone wolf category as both interconnectedness and resources are necessary to create the overlapping networks of effective people.

Our specific research questions were as follows: 1a) What social network infrastructure do lone wolves currently know about and use? 1b) What strategies for building relational networks will adequately support lone wolves, enable lone wolves to act effectively at their institutions, and utilize lone wolves in the effort to scale up change in engineering education? 2a) What kinds of social movement strategies (in what combinations and adaptations) will be effective in building power for change in engineering education? 2b) How can a root cause analysis based in social movement theories translate into/inform new strategies for action to change engineering education?

We conducted, transcribed, and coded 32 interviews with participants from a wide range of universities across the US. Interviewees were of every rank from graduate students to full professors, emeriti, and administrators. We (1) analyzed the data through organizational theory and gender theory lenses (2) conducted a comparison of themes and lessons learned from our interviews with social movements in higher education from the 1960s to the present; and (3) put our interview findings in conversation with findings from participant observation in feminist hackerspaces and open technology meetups to generate new approaches to engineering education reform and organizing toward enabling educators to seed the changes they seek.

Through our interviews with engineering education researchers we learned more specifics about the patchiness of the EER network. Individuals with alternative backgrounds, newcomers, and females reported challenges establishing and strengthening critical ties within the EER network. Additionally, individuals without specific advanced training or education in engineering found it particularly challenging to incorporate educational research into a traditionally technical profession. Many engineering education researchers reported tensions and difficulties in approaching reward structures at their institutions, exacerbated when they were lone practitioners in traditional engineering departments. We found evidence of gender homophily in EER, in which women face additional challenges in establishing network ties. We also found that distance from large, established engineering education departments seemed to hinder development of network ties, especially where isolated researchers reported not having the financial resources to fund travel, lodging, and conference fees for national meetings. Some of the isolated researchers reported attending local conferences, only to find that many of the more seasoned researchers attend national events, inhibiting the formation of important ties in the EER network.

Informed by these analyses, we conducted a participatory process to identify root causes of the current lack of diversity, equity, and justice in engineering education, and through that process went on to collaboratively develop and launch a campaign through a series of in-person meetings at conferences and conference calls with lone wolves and others. The result was the #EngineersShowUp Week of Action in February 2020 that built momentum and energy around critical understandings of diversity and concerted action for inclusion, equity, justice and strong allyship in engineering and beyond.

The #EngineersShowUp Week of Action facilitated a deepening of relationships in the work of change; amplified work already ongoing in the field; identified ways to move beyond surface conversations to engage various positionalities and complicity with oppression; and developed new learning modules and workshops to broach deeper discussions and action. Momentum was significantly disrupted by COVID but regained a new form amplifying the work of Black engineering faculty when they released a clear action list for universities, and contributing our lessons learned to the ASEE Commission on Diversity Equity and Inclusion's year of action. Engineers Show Up continue to leverage its network to distribute and amplify  a vareity of efforts, using our convening power to support lone wolves and continue reflection, discussion, and action in engineering education.
